item.title: Wiggle
item.description: Have a pesky patch that is only partially correct, and generates some .rej files. Use wiggle to apply the remaining changes in a safe fashion. How did I not know this before?

item.title: journald logs since last service restart.
item.description:
While debugging services I often want to see the systemd service log since last restart. Unfortunately doing this isn’t obvious, but there is a way.

$ journalctl _SYSTEMD_INVOCATION_ID=$(systemctl show --value -p InvocationID docker-hass)

where docker-hass is your service. I should probably add an alias for this to my dotfiles.

item.title: Queen's Gambit
item.description: We’ve been watching this show on Netflix every evening since it came out on friday, best mini series I’ve seen in years.

item.title: Remelting thermoplastics in salt
item.description: Very interesting method to increase the strength of 3D printed parts. The salt ensures the object retains its shape and can be washed away after the baking.

item.title: Deadpool
item.description: Been on a 3d model painting kick lately. This one is a work in progress but I think it’s starting to shape up. love how you can layer paint for continous improvement

item.title: Owl
Pair programming
item.description:
This graph is a good visualization of why I believe in pair programming.

Pair programming contributes to higher internal software quality. It can seem like a slow down at first, but you'll forget about that with the medium- and long-term impacts to the codebase and the product. pic.twitter.com/nEk5e7BsUz

— 🔥 Josh Branchaud 👻 (@jbrancha) August 31, 2020

To me this has always seemed intuitively right. Unfortunate that so many developers seem hesitant to participate in pair programming.

item.title: Free Cnc project files.
item.description: Some nice cnc projects, should give these a try.

item.title: Sandman The Audio Book
item.description: Just finished this, and it was glorious. Great voice acting, and I could almost see the comic strips from so long ago in my mind while reading. Weither you have good memories of the graphics novel, or you have ignored it because “comics aren’t real books”, I warmly recommended checking out this epic version of the story of the endless.

item.title: httpstat - great curl visualization
item.description:
Great little tool for seeing http timing stats.

TIL, httpstat: visualizes curl(1) statistics in a way of beauty and clarity -- nifty and instant replacement for my own curl timing script...

GitHub: https://t.co/L1jpopqyyq pic.twitter.com/eNzCQQzDoW

— Ilya Grigorik (@igrigorik) August 12, 2020

item.title: More praise for magit
item.description: I know I’ve mentioned magit before here, but I think this post shows a lot of the power you get from magit, which now makes it preferable to me even over the CLI.

item.title: Avoid 'no data' in your prometheus queries
item.description: CLOSED: [2020-08-10 Mon 20:57] Have some Prometheus queries that sometimes give no results? For instance error rate when there are no errors. Just append ~or vector(0) and the query will return 0 instead of an empty vector.

item.title: Magit Forge on macOS
item.description:
I’ve tried many editor git integrations over the years, in Vim, VS Code, IntelliJ, Sublime, as well as various git guis. However I’ve never found something nearly as powerful and efficient day to day as working on the command line.

While I will probably never give up the command line, with Emacs’ Magit I’ve finally found a valuable companion which feels as powerful and efficient as the cli interface. The magit status window is a super powerful base point for most git operations. And with Magit Forge you can make it even more powerful.

Now, to use Forge you need a github token. On macOS the best place to store such secrets is the OS Keychain, so I contributed a pull request to doom emacs to make it support the keychain for auth storage. Check out the MacOS doom module for more documentation.
